Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Postdoctoral Fellowships in Biology combine research and training components to prepare young scientists for careers in emerging areas where biology intersects with other scientific disciplines, in this case with engineering and statistics. The Fellows are expected to be leaders of the nation's scientific workforce of the future. This fellowship to Dr. Clay Wright supports research on how certain signaling molecules in plants have evolved to perceive distinctive developmental and environmental conditions and mediate dramatically different responses. The host institution for this fellowship is The University of Washington; sponsoring scientists are Drs. Jennifer Nemhauser and Eric Klavins . The Fellow's training goals include learning techniques and approaches of molecular evolution and plant biology, with emphasis on analytical and quantitative aspects. His outreach activities include training and mentoring graduate and undergraduate students and outreach to the public and educators through established programs, such as the Pacific Science Center?s Science Caf√©s and Expanding Your Horizons, and creating teaching materials.

The family of F-box-containing proteins has expanded significantly relative to other gene families throughout the evolution of modern plants. In plants, F-box proteins mediate numerous developmental responses to constantly changing environmental stimuli. Thus the expansion of the F-box family may reflect the ability of these proteins to rapidly evolve new specificities, creating novel signaling modules, and allowing plants to adapt when confronted with challenges such as drought, nutrient limitation, or new predators. This is being tested through quantitative analysis of the molecular evolution of F-box-containing plant hormone receptors. Very large sets of both prospective ancestral plant hormone receptor variants and chimeric variants of the two current plant hormone receptors are being created and functionally characterized using protein engineering techniques. This characterization is expected to provide insight into the development of diversity and specificity within the F-box family. Variants of particular interest are being introduced into plants to assess their effects on plant evolution. Additionally, the protein engineering platform developed in this work is expected to lead to the development of new F-box proteins. Such F-box proteins can be used as signaling modules to enhance the production of economically valuable crops, fuels, chemicals, biologicals, and pharmaceuticals. Applications of synthetic biology in this manner have increased access to food and medicine, while reducing cost, waste, and dependence on fossil fuels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As plants are immobile, they must be very good at sensing and adapting to their surroundings in order to grow and survive. Perhaps because of this fact, plants have complex networks of genes that allow them to generate, transport and respond to many different chemical signals. These chemical signals transfer messages about a plants growth and environment from one part of the plant to another to regulate future growth and development. Through this project, I have advanced our understanding of how plants detect one of these chemical signals. To do this I measured the ability of different plants of the same species that were collected from all over the world to perceive this chemical. I also measured how the roots of these different plants respond to this chemical. From these measurements and the genome sequences of these different plants, we now have a better idea of how we could change the genes that perceive this chemical to change the way plants grow. This will allow us to alter crop plants to be higher yielding or better suited for growing in different environments. Additionally, by understanding how plants perceive respond to these chemical signals we may one day be able to re-engineer these gene networks such that they respond specifically to chemicals of our choosing. This would allow farmers to control growth, flowering or defense responses. In this project, I have mapped only a small portion of the possible variation in the ability of plants to perceive a single chemical signal. However, this work has provided additional evidence supporting the current view of how plants perceive this chemical signal and has also revealed many new questions about the robustness the gene network. This work has demonstrated the power and utility of this technique on which I will build my future work towards these goals of re-engineering plant signaling.  

 

This fellowship has provided me the opportunity to train in plant molecular genetics, bioinformatics, and synthetic biology allowing me to develop unique independent lines of research to advance my career. I have gained experience in two new model organisms, which combine to yield a powerful way to quantify how chemical signals are sent and received by plants. I have gained a wealth of experience in writing grants and papers, developing software and mentoring students that will help move my career forward. I have published three peer-reviewed papers and developed one peer-reviewed software package during this fellowship. I have also shared my work within my field and to broader audiences while attending several conferences. I have mentored many students, from high school students to graduate students, through both research projects and career planning. Most of my mentees are from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in science, and I will continue to promote diversity in science throughout my career. I have also engaged the public in scientific activities and conversations through several events during my fellowship, including Building with Biology day at the Pacific Science Center and the Everett Public Schools Innovation Expo. These activities have generated some excellent conversations and learning experiences with kids and parents about synthetic biology.
